com.github.macgregor.alexandria

Class Resources.PathFinder

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.macgregor.alexandria.Resources.PathFinder
  • Enclosing class:
    Resources

    public static class Resources.PathFinder
extends Object
    Find files along a set of directories that based on include/exclude patterns. Makes use of FileUtils.listFiles(File, IOFileFilter, IOFileFilter) to do most of the work.

      • startingIn

        public Resources.PathFinder startingIn(String dir)
                                throws IOException
        Set starting directory to a single directory, converting it to a Path Path will be validated to be a directory that exists
        Parameters:
        dir - dir to use
        Returns:
        builder
        Throws:
        IOException - The path doesnt exist or is not a directory.

      • startingIn

        public Resources.PathFinder startingIn(Collection<String> dirs)
                                throws IOException
        Set the starting directories, converting the provided string paths into Path objects. Each path will be validated to be a directory that exists
        Parameters:
        dirs - dirs to use
        Returns:
        builder
        Throws:
        IOException - Any path doesnt exist or is not a directory.

      • recursive

        public Resources.PathFinder recursive(boolean isRecursive)
        When set, recursively walk directories when finding files. Default: true.
        Parameters:
        isRecursive - whether to use recursion or not
        Returns:
        builder

      • files

        public Collection<File> files()
        Find all files using the builder properties. Files will only be included if they match any of the include patterns and none of the exclude filters.
        Returns:
        List of matching File or an empty list.

      • paths

        public Collection<Path> paths()
        Same as files() but files are converted to Path objects before being returned.
        Returns:
        List of matching Path or an empty list.
